head.title: World Briefing | Africa: Climate Linked To Drop In Fish Population

hedline.hl1: World Briefing | Africa: Climate Linked To Drop In Fish Population

abstract.p: Research published in journal Nature has found herring catches in Africa's 400-mile-long Lake Tanganyika have diminished by 40% since 1970's; warming trend, effecting lake winds and seasonal shifts, has decreased natural food web; fish are vital to Burundi, Congo, Tanzania and Zambia, which all border lake; changes are linked to global warming (S)

block.p: Catches of two herring species have dropped about 40 percent since the 1970's in the 400-mile-long Lake Tanganyika in central Africa, and scientists now say they have linked the problem to rising temperatures and falling wind speeds in the region. The fish depend on a food web that is enriched as the deep fresh-water lake is stirred by seasonal shifts in winds and other conditions. That cycle has been disrupted by the warming, which matches the global trend scientists have linked to rising concentrations of heat-trapping greenhouse gases, the researchers said in a paper in the journal Nature. They said there were ''potentially dire'' consequences for the four countries bordering the lake -- Burundi, Congo, Tanzania and Zambia -- which get up to 40 percent of their animal protein from its fish.
